title: Bermuda targets younger travellers with America's Cup
text:
Bermuda targets younger travellers with America's Cup 21 July 2015 Save 
The Bermuda Tourism Authority (BTA) is using the forthcoming America’s Cup to promote the destination to a new market. 
Bill Hanbury, the chief executive of the BTA, said the destination has lost much of its sheen with younger travellers since its heyday as a tourist destination in the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s. 
And while he is still keen to work with established partners like Saga and various cruise companies, he is hoping the attraction of high-octane sailing racing will draw a new market both next year and in 2017 when up to seven crews could fight for one of the world’s biggest trophies in a series of up to 19 races. 
Hanbury said: “We have partners in the UK who we will continue to work with, but we’re actually looking for some new partners to customise some excursions and specific opportunities, not just in 2017 but before the event. 
“We’re looking for a new audience and we really need millennials and a younger demographic to get interested in Bermuda.” 
“We have a tremendous destination and is this what drives us. We still have that incredible destination, we just fell off the radar. 
“We want to find those additional travellers that are flying eight or nine hours to Dubai when they could be in Bermuda in five hours.” 
Hanbury added between 20,000 and 25,000 British tourists visited the island in 2014, about 10% of the entire tourist number for the year, with the US being the largest source market. 
As well as finding new partners, Hanbury said the authority has set aside up to $3.8 million in marketing spend for the next two and a half years to promote the destination, with up to 20% earmarked for the UK. He said money would be spent on PR and social media. 
He is hoping the 35th America’s Cup will help secure Bermuda in the minds of the British public as a British team, Land Rover BAR, which is captained by Sir Ben Ainslie, is entering the race.
